bibl.title: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Laura Armistead Carter, June 25, 1928

div1.p: Russell responds to Carter's inquiry about Noguchi's death in West Africa and tells her of the yellow fever deaths of Dr. Young and Dr. Stokes, stating that they were likely to have occurred from laboratory work inoculating animals in Africa.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Laura Armistead Carter, June 25, 1928

June 25, 1928.
Dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
I beg to thank you for your note of the 24th of June.
I am glad to know that the work is continuing satisfactorily.

We have heard from West Africa about the first half of Dr.
Noguchi's illness. At the time they wrote they had no clear idea as
to how Dr. Noguchi was infected, except that it was without any rea-
sonable doubt a laboratory infection, just as was the case with Dr.
Adrian Stokes. Dr. Noguchi, however, was working alone and we shall
probably never know any more.

Since then Dr. Young, the British medical officer in charge
of the laboratory at Accra, has died of yellow fever. He was also,
without any reasonable doubt infected in the laboratory. Probably
both infections occurred as the result of making animal inoculations,
or doing autopsies on animals. Dr. Stokes's infection was traced to
animal inoculations. He inoculated twelve monkeys one afternoon
with blood from a monkey at the height of the disease and was taken
ill four days afterwards. As you will see from a paper which is soon
to be published in the American Journal of Tropical Medicine, we have
learned that the virus will penetrate the unbroken skin of the monkey,
and it looks very much as if it would do the same thing with human skin.
